stages.description: Counting groups of 4 physical objects (cubes, counters, counting bears) arranged in equal groups, physically moving groups together to count in fours
stages.example_activity: Place 4 cubes in a cup. Add another 4 cubes to a second cup. Keep going. Count the running total each time: 4, 8, 12, 16...
stages.transition_cue: Child counts forwards and backwards in 4s from any given multiple of 4 without needing to arrange physical objects first

stages.description: Highlighting multiples of 4 on a hundred square, drawing jumps of 4 on a number line, using arrays to show groups of 4
stages.example_activity: Colour all multiples of 4 on a hundred square. Describe the pattern you see. Draw jumps of 4 on a number line starting from 20.
stages.transition_cue: Child identifies multiples of 4 without colouring or marking, and can continue a sequence from any starting multiple

stages.description: Reciting and writing multiples of 4 from any starting point, answering rapid-fire oral questions about the 4s sequence
stages.example_activity: What is the next multiple of 4 after 28? Count back in 4s from 48. Write the first 12 multiples of 4.
stages.transition_cue: Child responds instantly to 'what comes after/before' questions for any multiple of 4 without hesitation or finger-counting

stages.description: Counting groups of 8 physical objects, using the doubling connection to the 4 times table with paired groups of cubes
stages.example_activity: Build towers of 4 cubes. Now double each tower to make 8. Count the running total: 8, 16, 24, 32... Physically combine pairs of 4-towers.
stages.transition_cue: Child counts in 8s fluently using the doubling strategy without needing to build the 4s towers first

stages.description: Drawing the doubling connection between 4s and 8s on parallel number lines, highlighting multiples of 8 on a hundred square
stages.example_activity: Draw two number lines: one showing jumps of 4, one showing jumps of 8. Draw arrows connecting each multiple of 4 to its double on the 8s line.
stages.transition_cue: Child can identify whether a number is a multiple of 8 by checking the hundred square pattern, and can continue the 8s sequence from any multiple

stages.description: Reciting and writing multiples of 8, answering rapid-fire questions about the 8s sequence from any starting point
stages.example_activity: What is 7 × 8? Count back in 8s from 96. If I am at 56, what are the next three multiples of 8?
stages.transition_cue: Child recalls any multiple of 8 within 2 seconds and can count backwards in 8s through 0 without errors

stages.description: Counting stacks of 50p coins, grouping bundles of 50 straws, and using Dienes blocks to show groups of 50
stages.example_activity: Count out 50p coins one by one: 50, 100, 150, 200... Stack Dienes rods in groups of 5 tens to make 50 each time.
stages.transition_cue: Child counts fluently in 50s up to 1000 and back, including crossing hundreds boundaries, without handling coins or blocks

stages.description: Drawing jumps of 50 on a number line, marking multiples of 50 on a scale diagram (like a measuring jug marked in 50ml)
stages.example_activity: Draw a number line from 0 to 500. Mark jumps of 50. Now extend to 1000. Read the scale on a measuring jug marked in 50ml intervals.
stages.transition_cue: Child reads scales marked in 50s fluently and continues 50s sequences from any starting multiple without drawing

stages.description: Mentally counting in 50s from any starting multiple, answering rapid questions about 50s sequences
stages.example_activity: Start at 350 and count up in 50s to 700. What is 50 more than 650? What is 50 less than 400?
stages.transition_cue: Child responds without hesitation to 50-more/50-less questions across hundreds boundaries

stages.description: Counting Dienes hundreds flats, physically stacking or lining them up to count in hundreds from 0 to 1000
stages.example_activity: Place one hundred flat on the mat: 100. Add another: 200. Continue to 1000. Now remove one at a time: 1000, 900, 800...
stages.transition_cue: Child counts forwards and backwards in hundreds without touching the blocks, including crossing 1000

stages.description: Drawing jumps of 100 on a 0-1000 number line, identifying multiples of 100 on place value charts
stages.example_activity: Draw a number line from 0 to 1000 with marks at each hundred. Start at 300 and draw jumps of 100 forwards. Start at 900 and draw jumps back.
stages.transition_cue: Child identifies any multiple of 100 on an unmarked number line by reasoning about position

stages.description: Mentally counting in hundreds from any starting number, answering '100 more' and '100 less' questions instantly
stages.example_activity: What is 100 more than 700? Count back in hundreds from 1000. What number is 3 hundreds?
stages.transition_cue: Child answers hundred-more/hundred-less questions for any three-digit number without pause

stages.description: Using Dienes blocks on a place value mat to physically add or remove a tens rod from a three-digit number
stages.example_activity: Build 246 with Dienes blocks. Add one tens rod: now read the number (256). Remove one tens rod from 302: exchange a hundred for 10 tens first, then remove one ten (292).
stages.transition_cue: Child finds 10 more/less for numbers requiring exchange (e.g. 10 less than 300) without physical blocks, explaining the exchange verbally

stages.description: Using a place value chart or number line to show the effect of adding/removing 10, circling the tens digit that changes
stages.example_activity: Write 196 in a place value chart. Circle the tens digit. Add 10: what changes? The tens digit goes from 9 to 0, and the hundreds digit increases by 1. Draw this on a number line.
stages.transition_cue: Child explains the boundary crossing in their own words without needing the chart: 'The tens are full so I need to make another hundred'

stages.description: Answering rapid-fire '10 more' and '10 less' questions for any three-digit number, including boundary cases
stages.example_activity: 10 more than 196? 10 less than 300? 10 more than 990? Answer in under 3 seconds each.
stages.transition_cue: Child answers all boundary cases (tens digit 9 or 0) without hesitation and can explain why the hundreds digit changes

stages.description: Using Dienes blocks on a place value mat to physically add or remove a hundreds flat from a three-digit number
stages.example_activity: Build 324 with Dienes blocks. Add one hundreds flat: 424. Remove one hundreds flat from 324: 224. Try 100 more than 900 — you need a thousands cube!
stages.transition_cue: Child finds 100 more/less without blocks, correctly identifying that tens and ones digits stay the same

stages.description: Using place value charts and arrow cards to show only the hundreds digit changing when adding/removing 100
stages.example_activity: Write 467 in a place value chart. What changes when you add 100? Only the hundreds column: 567. Use arrow cards: swap the 400 card for a 500 card.
stages.transition_cue: Child consistently identifies the correct digit to change and handles the 900+100=1000 boundary correctly on paper

stages.description: Answering '100 more' and '100 less' questions instantly for any three-digit number
stages.example_activity: 100 more than 846? 100 less than 103? 100 more than 950? Answer each within 3 seconds.
stages.transition_cue: Child answers all questions including boundary cases without hesitation and explains reasoning using place value language

stages.description: Building three-digit numbers with Dienes blocks (hundreds flats, tens rods, ones cubes) on a place value mat labelled H, T, O
stages.example_activity: Build the number 347: place 3 hundreds flats, 4 tens rods and 7 ones cubes. Point to each group and say its value: three hundred, forty, seven.
stages.transition_cue: Child correctly states the value of each digit (not just the digit itself) when shown any three-digit Dienes arrangement: 'The 3 is worth 300'

stages.description: Using arrow cards, place value charts and part-whole models to represent three-digit numbers and their partitions
stages.example_activity: Use arrow cards: combine 300 + 40 + 7 to make 347. Draw a part-whole model showing 347 = 300 + 40 + 7. Now draw 307: what happens to the tens?
stages.transition_cue: Child partitions any three-digit number in standard form on paper without arrow cards, correctly handling zero placeholders

stages.description: Stating the value of any digit in a three-digit number and partitioning mentally in standard and flexible forms
stages.example_activity: What is the value of the 4 in 482? Partition 653 in three different ways. What number has 5 hundreds, 0 tens and 8 ones?
stages.transition_cue: Child instantly identifies digit values and partitions flexibly (e.g. 347 = 300 + 47 = 250 + 97) without written support

stages.description: Physically breaking Dienes block arrangements into different groupings to show standard and flexible partitions
stages.example_activity: Build 347. Standard partition: 3 hundreds, 4 tens, 7 ones. Now exchange one hundred for 10 tens: 2 hundreds, 14 tens, 7 ones. Is this still 347?
stages.transition_cue: Child creates flexible partitions by exchanging blocks confidently and confirms the total is unchanged each time

stages.description: Recording multiple partitions using part-whole models and bar models, showing standard and flexible forms
stages.example_activity: Draw three different part-whole models for 456: (400+50+6), (400+56), (300+156). Check each partition adds to 456.
stages.transition_cue: Child writes at least three different partitions for any three-digit number on paper, checking totals independently

stages.description: Mentally partitioning three-digit numbers in multiple ways and applying partitioning as a calculation strategy
stages.example_activity: Partition 482 in two non-standard ways. Use partitioning to calculate 347 + 200: 'I know 300 + 200 = 500, so 347 + 200 = 547.'
stages.transition_cue: Child spontaneously uses flexible partitioning during mental addition and subtraction without prompting

stages.description: Placing Dienes block representations of different numbers on a physical number line and comparing by inspection
stages.example_activity: Build 456 and 465 with Dienes blocks. Which has more hundreds? Same. Which has more tens? 465. Place them on the floor number line to check.
stages.transition_cue: Child compares two three-digit numbers by checking hundreds first, then tens, then ones, without building them physically

stages.description: Placing numbers on a printed number line, using place value charts side by side, and introducing > < = symbols
stages.example_activity: Place 378, 387 and 738 on a number line. Write comparisons using > and <. Order from smallest to largest.
stages.transition_cue: Child uses > < = symbols correctly and orders sets of 5+ numbers without a number line, explaining their systematic comparison

stages.description: Comparing and ordering any set of three-digit numbers using symbols and place value reasoning, without visual aids
stages.example_activity: Order 456, 465, 546, 564, 645, 654 from smallest to largest. Insert > or < between 389 __ 398.
stages.transition_cue: Child orders 6+ numbers correctly and explains their strategy: 'I compare hundreds first, then tens, then ones'

stages.description: Estimating quantities of physical objects (cubes in a jar, beads on a string) and marking estimated positions on a floor number line
stages.example_activity: How many cubes are in this jar? Walk to where you think the number goes on the floor number line. Count to check. How close was your estimate?
stages.transition_cue: Child consistently gives estimates within 100 of the actual count and uses benchmark reasoning: 'It looks like about half of 1000'

stages.description: Marking estimated positions on partially labelled number lines (marked only at 0, 500, 1000) and reading estimated values from scale diagrams
stages.example_activity: This number line shows 0 and 1000. Mark where 750 goes. This jug is marked at 0 and 500ml. The water is here — estimate the amount.
stages.transition_cue: Child places numbers on partially labelled number lines within 50 of the correct position and explains their reasoning using benchmarks

stages.description: Estimating answers to calculations and quantities in word problems without visual aids, using rounding to benchmarks
stages.example_activity: Estimate: 487 + 315. Think: 487 is about 500, 315 is about 300, so about 800. Is 743 closer to 700 or 800?
stages.transition_cue: Child routinely estimates before calculating, using rounding to the nearest hundred, and identifies unreasonable answers

stages.description: Building numbers with Dienes blocks and matching to printed word cards, physically associating blocks with words
resources: word cards (one to nine hundred, and, twenty, thirty... etc.)
stages.example_activity: Build 347 with blocks. Find the word cards: 'three hundred', 'and', 'forty-seven'. Lay them out. Match to the numeral card 347.
stages.transition_cue: Child reads the word form of any three-digit number shown in blocks and matches words to numerals without errors

stages.description: Writing numbers in words using a reference chart of ones and teens spellings, and converting between numeral and word forms on paper
stages.example_activity: Write 'three hundred and seven' as a numeral. Write 458 in words. Circle the numbers that need 'and' in their word form.
stages.transition_cue: Child writes any three-digit number in words correctly, including those with zero in the tens place, without the reference chart

stages.description: Reading and writing any number to 1000 in words and numerals fluently, including dictated numbers
stages.example_activity: Write in words: 906, 550, 111. Write as numerals: 'seven hundred and sixty-three'. Spell-check: is 'four hundred and fourty' correct?
stages.transition_cue: Child spells all number words to 1000 correctly and converts between forms in both directions without errors
